q: Allen Iverson 's still hurting Former All-Star Allen Iverson , 35, could miss the rest of the regular season and the playoffs with Turkish team Besiktas because of painful calcium deposits in his calf. He tried to tough it out and continue to play while over in Turkey, said Dr. James Andrews, who added Allen Iverson needs at least 6-8 weeks of rest. "However, he got to the point where he could not really run up and down the court." Back

We didn't do that in the Pentagon. I insisted we not do it. Donald Rumsfeld added that although Colin Powell may now argue that he was against the war in Iraq, Donald Rumsfeld saw no sign of Colin Powell 's dissenting position while both men served together in the President Bush administration.

Next up, Jaime Anderson tells me, they'll be making-over a pit bull in the wake of perpetually gauche Dwaine Caraway 's weekend spent buddying up to noted animal abuser and convicted felon Michael Vick . She writes: This will be more of an "image' makeover, but we plan to parade a pit around in a pink tutu and show how "vicious' they really are( not)! Kevin Johnson talks about how traffic is increasing at a faster rate than the number of users and how the model will not scale. He notes the need for new business models and an increase in innovation. Windows Azure is in a great place, and Amitabh Srivastava is ready to move to a new phase in his career. He has done stellar work for the company and I will work to ensure a smooth transition with the Windows Azure team, said Steve Ballmer . It's thought that Amitabh Srivastava 's exit is connected to Microsoft's announcement that company veteran Satya Nadella would replace Bob Muglia as head of Server and Tools. government repays others who invest in U.S. Treasury bonds. "It's an IOU that is backed by Treasury bonds and the faith and credit of the United States government," said Sen. Bernie Sanders , I-Vt. It is the same faith and credit that enables us to borrow from rich people and from China and from other countries. As you well know, in the history of this country, the United States has never defaulted on one penny owed to a creditor.
